block.p: THEY'RE NO. 1 Toyota Motor Company officially took over bragging rights from General Motors as the world's largest automaker, prompting a round of finger pointing in Detroit over what went wrong, and what G.M. should do to regain its global leadership. [Page C1.]

NO CIVIL CHARGES FOR APPLE Federal securities regulators said they would bring no civil charges against Apple over the backdating of executive stock options. But they stopped short of removing the cloud that for nearly a year has hung over Steven P. Jobs. [C1.]
F.D.A. QUESTIONS LILLY DATA The Food and Drug Administration is examining whether Eli Lilly & Company provided it with accurate data about the side effects of the antipsychotic drug Zyprexa. [C1.]

A BIAS SUIT IS SETTLED Morgan Stanley will pay at least $46 million to settle a suit filed by current and former female brokers who said that they were discriminated against in how they were trained, promoted and paid. The settlement aims to overhaul the way accounts are distributed in the firm's retail branches. [C1.]

PAY TO BURN Gazprom, the Russian energy giant that sells natural gas to Europe, has begun selling carbon dioxide emissions credits that companies in the European Union need to burn Gazprom's fuel. [C4.]
SALES OF EXISTING HOMES PLUNGE Sales of previously owned homes took their biggest tumble in nearly two decades last month, dashing hopes that the housing market had stabilized. [C2.]

VONAGE CAN SIGN NEW CUSTOMERS Vonage, the Internet phone company embroiled in a bitter patent suit with Verizon, can continue signing up new customers, a federal appeals court in Washington ruled. ''It's business as usual for us,'' said Jeffrey A. Citron, above, Vonage's chairman and interim chief executive. [C4.]

BETTING ON CHEAP FARES Skybus Airlines, a well-financed start-up based in Columbus, Ohio, that promises some $10 seats on every flight, will begin service on May 22, returning the extremely low-fare airline to the United States. [C12.]

VIRGIN ATLANTIC ORDERS PLANES Virgin Atlantic Airways ordered 15 fuel-efficient Boeing 787 planes as part of an environmental partnership with the company that includes joint research into biofuels for use in jet engines. [C12.]

A WARNING FROM ALCATEL-LUCENT Alcatel-Lucent warned investors of continued losses and weak sales, casting doubt about the long-term outlook for the company four months after completing a trans-Atlantic merger. Share prices dropped after the announcement, but later made a strong recovery. [C18.]

OSHA'S RULES HAVE BEEN LOOSENED Since George W. Bush became president, appointees to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration have eased regulations or weakened enforcement of rules on issues like driving hours for truckers, logging in forests and corporate mergers, while issuing the fewest significant standards in its history, public health experts say. [A1.]

DELIVER CUSTOMERS, OR ELSE The frenetic competition in the automotive industry is taking its toll on the advertising industry. In recent months the makers of six auto brands decided to re-evaluate the relationships with the agencies that worked for them. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.]

SHAREHOLDERS WITHHOLD VOTES Shareholders of The New York Times Company gave voice to their displeasure with the company's management and financial performance by withholding votes representing 42 percent of the Class A shares at the annual meeting. [C5.]

MIXED NEWS FOR MARKETS Wall Street closed mixed, but the Dow briefly reached a new trading high as investors weighed disappointing data on housing sales and consumer confidence against stronger-than-expected quarterly earnings. [C14.]

ACQUITTAL IN INDONESIA An Indonesian court acquitted Newmont Mining Corporation, the American mining giant, and one of its executives on charges of polluting a bay here with toxic waste from a now defunct gold mine, in a case that became a litmus test of foreign investor confidence in Indonesia. [A8.]
ONLINE
Business Briefing
Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.

THE CHEMICAL MAKER DUPONT reported a 16 percent increase in first-quarter earnings as strong performance in its agricultural unit helped offset sluggish demand for products in the domestic housing and automotive markets. (AP)

SHARES IN WHIRLPOOL, which makes home appliances, soared past $100 for the first time as the company said it would resume share buybacks that it had suspended while it digested its purchase of rival Maytag. (AP)
UNITED STATES STEEL reported that first-quarter profit rose 6.6 percent on strong growth in European operations. (AP)
THE PEPSI BOTTLING GROUP said that quarterly profit fell nearly 15 percent on higher raw material costs, but the results beat Wall Street's consensus because of tight expense controls. (REUTERS)
